Posts.Content: Aug 3, 2009 10:37AM elliem1207 wrote: shauna, my cea markers and ca 27-29 numbers are dead on for me--when they go up--the beast is on the move. mine don't go excedingly high, but whenever they go up--there's progression. i have been on a 2 month taxol break due to neuropathy, but my last blood test-- both markers jumped--so i'm back on the taxol again. it was a good 2 months--but ya know what they say--all good things come to an end. take care, ellie xx

Posts.Content: elliem1207 wrote: hi, haven't posted in a while, but i check in every day to see how everyone is doing. i had my regular onc appt on the 15th. told him i was having pain across the middle of my back, he scheduled a cat scan and i have mets to the spine along with a compression fracture to my t8 verterbrae. i have been on tamoxifen since march and had a good scan in june. now i'm a bit confused because there is no more progression in my lung--but now it is in my spine. so i'm assuming the tamoxifen must have been working on the lung nodules, but he's taking me off the tamoxifen and hasn't decided yet what the next treatment will be other than monthly zometa. i just had my 3rd rad treatment today. will be doing a total of 14. but i have alot of pain and it's not getting better. is it usual to have so much pain with mets to spine/compression fracture? i have a call into the onc, but you now how that goes. i thought i would ask here because i will get more info from you girls than i will from the dr. any info would be appreciated. ellie ~~ Always keep people in your life that charge your battery, not those who drain it. ~~ Dx 11/2007, Stage IV, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: compression fracture elliem1207 mthomp2020

What Cancer Cannot Do It cannot cripple Love It cannot shatter Faith It cannot corrode Hope It cannot kill Friendship It cannot suppress Memories It cannot silence Courage It cannot invade the Soul It cannot steal Eternal Life It cannot conquer the Spirit ~~ Always keep people in your life that charge your battery, not those who drain it. ~~ Dx 11/2007, Stage IV, ER+/PR-, HER2- Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Aug 22, 2008 02:06AM elliem1207 wrote: hi robin, i was hoping you would let us know how things went. i am back on tamoxifen for one last try. i started taking it in march after i had more progression with the aromasin. i have major gastrointestinal issues with tamoxifen, that's why i stopped taking it after my first dx back in 2001. my onc asked me if i wanted to try it one more time before starting chemo --  i figured what the hell. he gave me anti-nausea medication, ativan, effexor and pretty much anything else i want. i still have major issues with the tamoxifen but my last scan in june showed modest improvement, so i'll take whatever mileage i can get out of this drug. i did ask him if this would eventually fail and he said it would. i hope you're going to give it a try--i've gotten 5 months so far, i have my next scan in oct, hopefully there will be more improvement. was it a madhouse at df today? ellie
Posts.Title: Back from Boston with a surprising treatment recommendation RobinWendy roseg

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2009 02:45PM elliem1207 wrote: talking about the dryer brings back a memory that we always laugh at my house. my son must have been 16 at the time, and you know how the testosterone kicks in. well, he did his laundry but apparently forgot to empty the pockets. washed his clothes then off in the dryer they go. my 13 yr old daughter wanted the dryer so as she's taking out  his clothes to put in the laundry basket, i hear her running up the stairs screaming like girls scream. well as it turned out a packaged condom was sitting at the bottom of the dryer. of course she's a drama queen, so you can imagine all the drama that followed. my son(out of embarrassment) still claims to this day that it wasn't his. just doesn't know how a condom ended up in the bottom of the dryer.

Posts.Content: Apr 10, 2008 05:00PM elliem1207 wrote: hi kasey i have been going to dana farber since 2001. i switched from one of our local hospitals after my biopsy. i would recommend it as they do clinical trials--my onc said they are doing a new trial now but i am not able to participate because i have fluid in my lung and the drug would collect in the fluid--i don't know much else about the trial. my sister was in a clinical trial at dana for ovarian cancer 3 yrs ago and she is been in remission since then. i travel 1 1/2 hrs each way, but i feel like i am getting the best possible care available here. the only drawback is that it is always so very very busy all the time. i hope this helped. ellie

Posts.Content: Feb 6, 2009 08:56AM elliem1207 wrote: susan, i have been to that dark place many many nights--i would lie there and think about dying -- i would get up and start writing my obituary--i would think about who would come to my funeral and what songs i  wanted played--i mentioned to my onc about my dark place and he put me on ativan,0.5 mg before bed--i find that it mellows me out--i sleep all night long and i'm not a zombie in the morning--the 1 mg makes me very woozy in the am so i only take .5--i have never been a good pill taker person, but this works for me.  i hope you find something that works for you. ellie xoxo
